resources.string: Sunnyside Beach is the closest it’s been to the hub of activity it represented before the Gardiner cut it off from the rest of the city in 1955. Following a section of the Martin Goodman Trail, its lake air and lapping waves make it a preferred commuting route for west end cyclists, rollerbladers and joggers, Sunnyside Pavilion is a popular rendezvous for watersports like competitive rowing, stand up paddleboarding, and canoe and kayak rentals, and the sandy patches that dot the coast are alive with sunbathers, Frisbee, and beach volleyball, and while the beach isn’t always safe for swimming, there’s always the free pool.
Park consisting of four main islands and containing trails, beaches and children\'s amusement rides.

One of the Port Lands’s few saving graces, Cherry Beach offers the industrial neighbourhood a leafy green contrast and attractive integration with Lake Ontario. Added bonus for seaworthy beach bums: it’s conveniently situated across the channel from Ward’s Island, so save your ferry fare.

Hinging Toronto and Mississauga at the mouth of Etobicoke Creek in Long Branch, the beach at Marie Curtis Park is a tranquil space flanked by willow trees and suburban housing. At the intersection of several communities and their shared histories, it was originally created in the late 1950s to help control flooding after Hurricane Hazel swept Lake Ontario. Today, City of Toronto parks staff are working with the Region of Peel and Credit Valley Conservation on a design for a new greenspace that will connect the park with the Inspiration Lakeview Lands.

Like the urban beach at HTO Park, Sugar Beach is another sandy bar with Muskoka chairs and big shady umbrellas that look out onto Lake Ontario, but here they’re powder pink. And no, no swimming here, either, so you won’t have to share those seats with abandoned towels.
This luxurious hotel features a rooftop patio with heated whirlpools overlooking the city centre of Toronto. Guests may enjoy a gourmet restaurant and free Wi-Fi. Union Station is 2 km away.
DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel Toronto Downtown

Located in the city centre, DoubleTree by Hilton Toronto Downtown boasts an indoor heated pool, an on-site restaurant, and a fitness centre. Toronto Eaton Centre and St. Patrick Subway Station are within 350 m.\n

This 4-star hotel in Toronto is located in the Rogers Centre sports and entertainment complex. The hotel features Arriba, a Mediterranean restaurant, and an indoor pool. Pearson International Airport is 26 km away.\n
Toronto Marriott Downtown Eaton Centre Hotel
Located in Toronto Eaton Centre, this hotel is connected to PATH underground walkway. Trios Bistro is on site and a 32-inch flat-screen TV is featured in rooms. Dundas Subway Station is 350 m away.\n
Centrally located between Toronto\'s Financial and Entertainment Districts, this luxury hotel offers an indoor pool, hot tub and on-site restaurant. An iPad is featured in all the guest rooms.\n
Popular urban oasis offers a variety of outdoor recreation including ice-skating, baseball games, nature hikes and exploring the park\'s greenhouse.\n

Explore the Waters of the World at Ripley\'s Aquarium of Canada. Located in the heart of downtown Toronto at the base of the CN Tower, the aquarium is Toronto\'s newest must-see attraction for tourists and locals of all ages.\n

The CN Tower is a National icon, engineering Wonder, a Toronto must-see attraction and award winning dining and entertainment destination. Rocket to the top aboard the Tower\'s glass fronted and glass floor paneled elevators which take you to the top in only 58 seconds. Take in spectacular views of up to 160km (100 miles) away from four observation areas on three levels, including the LookOut, world famous Glass Floor with outdoor SkyTerrace and the SkyPod, the highest of them all. Experience the thrill of EdgeWalk at the CN Tower, the World\'s Highest Outdoor Walk on a Building. Enjoy award-winning Canadian cuisine and breathtaking revolving views at 360 The Restaurant at the CN Tower, family friendly fare at Horizons Toronto celebrating the multicultural flavours of Toronto neighbourhoods, or grab and go fare from Le Café. Plus, visual displays, KidZone play area and 8,000 square feet of unique Canadian artisan and souvenir shopping in the Gift Shop. Don\'t miss the architectural illumination of the CN Tower each night from dusk with top of the hour light show.\n

The Royal Ontario Museum (ROM) is among the world’s leading museums of natural history and world cultures. In combining a universal museum of cultures with that of natural history, the ROM offers an unusual breadth of experience to our audiences from around the world. We realize more acutely now that nature and humanity are intertwined, and the ROM offers many examples in its collections and programs of these fundamental relationships.\n
